DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term that represents the pathologic stage for lymphoma using the Ann Arbor Lymphoma Staging System.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Lymphoma Pathologic Ann Arbor Lymphoma Staging System
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A malignant (clonal) proliferation of B- lymphocytes or T- lymphocytes which involves the lymph nodes, bone marrow and/or extranodal sites. This category includes Non-Hodgkin lymphomas and Hodgkin lymphomas._Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology._The Ann Arbor system classifies lymphoma into four stages based on anatomic lymph nodal group involvement. Disease confined to one nodal group or location defines stage I. Disease limited to one side of the diaphragm, (the muscle separating the chest from the abdomen), defines stage II. Stage III patients have disease on both sides of the diaphragm and stage IV patients once again have disseminated disease. Consideration of involvement of the liver, spleen, and bone marrow are also considered in this system. Finally, the stage is subdivided into categories of A and B depending on the presence of symptoms of itching, weight loss, fever, and night sweats. Those having symptoms receive the designation "B" and have a worse prognosis.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A malignant (clonal) proliferation of B- or T- lymphocytes which involves the lymph nodes, bone marrow and/or extranodal sites.  This category includes Non-Hodgkin's lymphomas and Hodgkin's lymphomas. -- 2003

Concepts.definition: A malignant (clonal) proliferation of B- lymphocytes or T- lymphocytes which involves the lymph nodes, bone marrow and/or extranodal sites. This category includes Non-Hodgkin lymphomas and Hodgkin lymphomas.

Property.preferredName: Pathologic Ann Arbor Lymphoma Staging System
Property.preferredDefinition: Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.:The Ann Arbor system classifies lymphoma into four stages based on anatomic lymph nodal group involvement. Disease confined to one nodal group or location defines stage I. Disease limited to one side of the diaphragm, (the muscle separating the chest from the abdomen), defines stage II. Stage III patients have disease on both sides of the diaphragm and stage IV patients once again have disseminated disease. Consideration of involvement of the liver, spleen, and bone marrow are also considered in this system. Finally, the stage is subdivided into categories of A and B depending on the presence of symptoms of itching, weight loss, fever, and night sweats. Those having symptoms receive the designation "B" and have a worse prognosis.

Concepts.definition: Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.

The Ann Arbor system classifies lymphoma into four stages based on anatomic lymph nodal group involvement. Disease confined to one nodal group or location defines stage I. Disease limited to one side of the diaphragm, (the muscle separating the chest from the abdomen), defines stage II. Stage III patients have disease on both sides of the diaphragm and stage IV patients once again have disseminated disease. Consideration of involvement of the liver, spleen, and bone marrow are also considered in this system. Finally, the stage is subdivided into categories of A and B depending on the presence of symptoms of itching, weight loss, fever, and night sweats. Those having symptoms receive the designation "B" and have a worse prognosis.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Created for GDC new CDE request. mc 1/5/17

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The extent of a cancer in the body. Staging is usually based on the size of the tumor, whether lymph nodes contain cancer, and whether the cancer has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A pathologic stage that refers to lymphoma involving a single lymph node region or a single extranodal organ (Ie).

Concepts.definition: A pathologic stage that refers to lymphoma involving a single lymph node region or a single extranodal organ (Ie).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A pathologic stage that refers to lymphoma involving two or more node regions on the same side of the diaphragm or a single extranodal organ plus its regional lymph nodes with or without other nodes on the same side of the diaphragm (IIe).

Concepts.definition: A pathologic stage that refers to lymphoma involving two or more node regions on the same side of the diaphragm or a single extranodal organ plus its regional lymph nodes with or without other nodes on the same side of the diaphragm (IIe).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A pathologic stage that refers to lymphoma involving node regions on both sides of the diaphragm, or an extralymphatic organ or site plus nodes on both sides of the diaphragm (IIIe), or lymph nodes on both sides of the diaphragm plus spleen (IIIs).

Concepts.definition: A pathologic stage that refers to lymphoma involving node regions on both sides of the diaphragm, or an extralymphatic organ or site plus nodes on both sides of the diaphragm (IIIe), or lymph nodes on both sides of the diaphragm plus spleen (IIIs).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A pathologic stage that refers to diffuse extralymphatic involvement by lymphoma.

Concepts.definition: A pathologic stage that refers to diffuse extralymphatic involvement by lymphoma.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.definition: The extent of a cancer in the body.

ValueDomain.changeDescription: Created for Quick Question request by T. Lichtenberg. 3.27.18 mc

DataElement.changeDescription: Created for new CDE request. mc 1/5/17 Changed VD per request by T. Lichtenberg to separate out clinical and pathologic stages. 3.28.18 mc
